'''The Game''' (always capitalized) is a title given to several [[United States of America|U.S.]] [[college football]] [[Sports rivalry|rivalry]] games, but most particularly the annual contest between '''Harvard''' and '''Yale'''.{{Fact|date=November 2008}} As of 2008, the [[Harvard University|Harvard]] [[Harvard Crimson|Crimson]] and [[Yale University|Yale]] [[Yale Bulldogs|Bulldogs]] have met 125 times beginning in 1875, when [[American football]] was evolving from [[Rugby football|rugby]]. The Harvard-Yale game is played in November at the end of the football season, and the venue alternates between [[Harvard Stadium]] and the [[Yale Bowl]]. As of 2008, Yale leads the series 65-52-8.
â

The Game is the oldest and also the third-most-played college football rivalry, after [[The Rivalry (Lehigh-Lafayette)|The Rivalry]] between Lehigh-Lafayette and the Princeton-Yale game. In 2003, the rivalry was rated the sixth-best in college athletics by ''[[Sports Illustrated]] On Campus'', after [[Army-Navy Game|Army-Navy]], [[Iron Bowl|Alabama-Auburn]], [[UNC-Duke rivalry|Duke-North Carolina]], [[UCLA-USC rivalry|UCLA-USC]], and [[Big Game (football)|Cal-Stanford]].

â
'''The Game''' (always capitalized) is a title given to several [[United States of America|U.S.]] [[college football]] [[Sports rivalry|rivalry]] games, but most particularly the annual contest between '''Harvard''' and '''Yale'''.{{Fact|date=November 2008}} As of 2008, the [[Harvard University|Harvard]] [[Harvard Crimson|Crimson]] and [[Yale University|Yale]] [[Yale Bulldogs|Bulldogs]] have met 125 times beginning in 1875, when [[American football]] was evolving from [[Rugby football|rugby]]. The Harvard-Yale game is played in November at the end of the football season, and the venue alternates between [[Harvard Stadium]] and the [[Yale Bowl]]. As of 2008, Yale leads the series 65-52-8.
  â
The Game is the oldest and also the third-most-played college football rivalry, after [[The Rivalry (Lehigh-Lafayette)|The Rivalry]] between Lehigh-Lafayette and the Princeton-Yale game. In 2003, the rivalry was rated the sixth-best in college athletics by ''[[Sports Illustrated]] On Campus'', after [[Army-Navy Game|Army-Navy]], [[Iron Bowl|Alabama-Auburn]], [[UNC-Duke rivalry|Duke-North Carolina]], [[UCLA-USC rivalry|UCLA-USC]], and [[Big Game (football)|Cal-Stanford]].
  â   â
==History==
  â
{{see also|List of Harvard-Yale football games}}
 
The first meeting between the teams occurred on [[November 13]], [[1875]] at Hamilton Field in [[New Haven]]. Harvard won 4-0 by scoring four touchdowns and four field goals (at the time, a touchdown merely gave the scoring team the opportunity to gain one point by converting the field goal). This was the first intercollegiate football match between two U.S. teams. (Harvard had played [[McGill University]] of [[Montreal]] the previous year, and acquired the rules of the game from that team; previous intercollegiate matches were played under the rules of [[soccer]], or European football.)
The first meeting between the teams occurred on [[November 13]], [[1875]] at Hamilton Field in [[New Haven]]. Harvard won 4-0 by scoring four touchdowns and four field goals (at the time, a touchdown merely gave the scoring team the opportunity to gain one point by converting the field goal). This was the first intercollegiate football match between two U.S. teams. (Harvard had played [[McGill University]] of [[Montreal]] the previous year, and acquired the rules of the game from that team; previous intercollegiate matches were played under the rules of [[soccer]], or European football.)
Line 39: Line 34:
==Significance==
==Significance==
â
[[Image:Yale-Harvard-Game.jpg|thumb|300px|Half-time festivities at The Game, [[Yale Bowl]].]]
 
For many students and alumni of Harvard and Yale, The Game is an important event. The schools are located only a few hours' travel from one another; and, perhaps because they are among the nation's most prestigious and oldest universities, the rivalry is intense. Beating the rival is often considered more important than the team's season record. Furthermore, since [[Ivy League]] schools do not participate in post-season football games, The Game is usually the final game of the season (except for 1919, when Harvard beat Yale 3-0 and went on to the [[Rose Bowl (game)|Rose Bowl]], where they defeated Oregon 7-6); since most Ivy League football players do not go on to professional careers in the sport (the league does not offer athletic scholarships), it is almost always the graduating seniors' final organized game.
For many students and alumni of Harvard and Yale, The Game is an important event. The schools are located only a few hours' travel from one another; and, perhaps because they are among the nation's most prestigious and oldest universities, the rivalry is intense. Beating the rival is often considered more important than the team's season record. Furthermore, since [[Ivy League]] schools do not participate in post-season football games, The Game is usually the final game of the season (except for 1919, when Harvard beat Yale 3-0 and went on to the [[Rose Bowl (game)|Rose Bowl]], where they defeated Oregon 7-6); since most Ivy League football players do not go on to professional careers in the sport (the league does not offer athletic scholarships), it is almost always the graduating seniors' final organized game.
